body.p: We've had past blog posts about how Oxygen can be used to impose various editing behaviors for your team and in this blog post we are going to try and bring all these solutions together in a larger overview.

section.title: Learning to work with DITA and Oxygen
section.p: You can find useful links for learning to edit DITA using Oxygen in this previous blog post: http://blog.oxygenxml.com/2016/03/resources-for-learning-dita-with-oxygen.html.

section.title: Migrating to DITA
section.p: There are multiple reasons why you would want to migrate from unstructured content to structured: http://blog.oxygenxml.com/2015/12/migrating-to-structured-standards-based.html.

This older blog post details some possibilities of migrating Word documents to DITA: http://blog.oxygenxml.com/2016/05/how-to-migrate-from-word-to-dita.html. But you also have ways to migrate from XML-based standards like DocBook or XHTML to DITA using a set of predefined transformation scenarios.

section.title: Implementing your own Style Guide
section.p: Let's say you are a team of tech writers collaborating on a DITA-based project and doing things your way, maybe you have various best practices about what elements to use and when to use them. So at some point you gather on an internal server a set of HTML resources which explain how various DITA elements should be used. And you want all the team members to have access to that set of HTML resources directly from Oxygen.
This blog post should have more details and useful links to get you started: http://blog.oxygenxml.com/2016/03/implementing-your-own-style-guide.html

section.title: Imposing Controlled Attribute Values
section.p: If you want to impose values which need to be set for profiling or general-use DITA attributes this blog post should cover all you need to know about this: http://blog.oxygenxml.com/2015/07/controlled-attribute-values-for-your.html

section.title: Restricting the Visual Editing Experience
section.p: The entire visual editing experience using the Author editing mode in Oxygen is CSS driven. Oxygen has support for defining various CSS layers which can be applied when editing DITA content. For example if you choose to create a LightWeight DITA topic in Oxygen it has a special editing layer which allows it to be edited with a combination of buttons, hints and form controls.

section.title: Imposing Business Rules and Structure Restrictions to the DITA content
section.p: Most of the times, instead of relying on people to memorize various internal documentation style rules, you can convert those rules to Schematron, allowing the application to automatically signal to the writer when a rule is not obeyed. You can also add quick fixes to show writers various ways to rectify the problem. This blog post should give you more details about this:http://blog.oxygenxml.com/2015/05/schematron-checks-to-help-technical.html.

section.title: Running Batch Validation Checks on all of you DITA content
section.p: The Validate and Check For Completeness tool available in the DITA Maps Manager view performs a lot if different consistency checks on all your DITA topics. It can also be used to apply Schematron business rules on all your topics: http://blog.oxygenxml.com/2015/12/dita-map-validate-and-check-for.html.

section.title: Sharing DITA Editing Customizations With Your Team
section.p: Most of the custom editing behaviors, toolbar and menu buttons that are available when editing DITA content are defined in the DITA framework configuration. A framework configuration's general anatomy is described here: http://blog.oxygenxml.com/2014/08/the-oxygen-sdk-part-2-frameworks.html.

The framework configuration can be shared with all your team members. For example here's a way to disallow team members from using certain DITA elements: http://blog.oxygenxml.com/2015/08/document-type-extension-sharing.html. And here's a way to distribute new DITA file templates to your team: http://blog.oxygenxml.com/2015/12/sharing-new-custom-file-templates-for.html.

section.title: Sharing Global Application Settings With Your Team
section.p: Let's say you want all your team members to enable the automatic spell checker when writing documentation or you want all of them to use a custom term dictionary or a custom set of learned words. This older blog post should give you some hints about how global Oxygen settings can be distributed to your team members: http://blog.oxygenxml.com/2015/11/sharing-application-settings.html.

section.title: Collaboration, Content Management and Version Tracking
section.p: All major Component Management Systems (CMSs) have plugins which can be installed in Oxygen to provide access to the CMS: https://www.oxygenxml.com/partners.html#cmssolutionpartners. But even if you lack the funds to buy a commercial CMS there are still plenty of open source version tracking solutions which allow collaboration on a single DITA project: http://blog.oxygenxml.com/2013/12/collaboration-teams-working-on-common.html. For example the Oxygen User's Manual is written in DITA and we use a GitHub private repository to collaborate on it: http://blog.oxygenxml.com/2014/11/collaboration-for-documenting-software.html.

section.title: Allowing Subject Matter Experts to Review Content
section.p: Many technical writers are interested in having their content reviewed by the engineers who are directly involved in building the tools. Oxygen has support for change tracking and for adding comments directly in the edited content. Engineers do not necessarily need to have the standalone version of Oxygen installed. The Oxygen Web Author is an online editing and reviewing solution which allows engineers to add comments and propose changes directly on the DITA content by using any device with a web browser (laptop, tablet, phone): https://www.oxygenxml.com/xml_web_author.html.

body.p: I hope this overview will help you implement a complete guided authoring experience using Oxygen. If you have any questions and suggestions, they are as usual welcomed.
